questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of arm pain following a fall that took place 5 hours ago. According to his mother, the boy was running in the yard when he fell and injured his right arm. The boy is crying and clutching his arm. During the past year, he has been brought in 4 other times for extremity pain following falls, all of which have been diagnosed as long bone fractures. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 97/68 mm Hg. His right forearm is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when his forearm is touched. His left arm has two small ecchymotic regions overlying the elbow and wrist. A photograph of his eyes is shown. An x-ray of the right forearm shows a transverse mid-ulnar fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type 5 collagen is a regulator of type 1 collagen fibrillogenesis. Type 5 collagen defects usually manifest as classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by chronic joint and bone issues. Rather than frequent bone fractures, the major symptoms are joint instability, early onset of osteoarthritis, hyperflexible joints, and scoliosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Non-accidental injury, i.e., child abuse, must always be considered in the differential diagnosis of children with growth retardation and concomitant fractures, especially those with multiple or recurrent fractures such as this boy. However, the presence of osteopenia suggests a metabolic disease as the cause. Additionally, the finding of blue sclerae is unique to patients with osteogenesis imperfecta, who have sclerae that are thinner than usual and allow the underlying choroidal veins to shine through.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 2 collagen defects predominantly affect tissues such as cartilage and vitreous humor. Various conditions are associated with type 2 collagen defects (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia, or osteoarthritis) and these differ substantially in presentation and age of onset. While some conditions could explain the growth retardation observed in this patient (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia), blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures in an otherwise healthy child would not be consistent with any type 2 collagen defect.

D) INCORRECT:

The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type 4) arises from an autosomal mutation in type 3 collagen. This condition manifests predominantly in the cardiovascular system and often goes undiagnosed until it becomes apparent through some sort of vascular damage/injury (e.g., aortic dissection, ruptures arterial aneurysm, subarachnoid hemorrhage). The child presents with easy bruising, as evidenced by the ecchymosis, which is also a feature of Ehlers-Danlos type 4. However, the child's history of frequent fractures after minor trauma, the blue sclerae, and growth retardation are not consistent with this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children, which manifests with growth retardation, bone deformities, and osteopenia. However, blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures are not seen in rickets. Patients at risk for developing vitamin D deficiency include premature infants, dark-skinned children on vegetarian and unusual diets, children living at higher latitudes, and children with malabsorption conditions. This patient has none of these risk factors.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutations to the genes encoding type 4 collagen can manifest as Alport syndrome. This disorder usually affects boys, who present with intermittent gross hematuria, hearing loss, and ocular disturbances, none of which are seen here. Recurrent bone fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclerae are not features of Alport syndrome.

G) CORRECT:

A mutation in type 1 collagen causes osteogenesis imperfecta type 1, the mildest and most common form of osteogenesis imperfecta. In fact, some patients with osteogenesis imperfecta type 1 appear normal and without obvious deformities to the casual observer despite requiring special accommodations for their bone fragility.

The prognosis depends heavily on the type of osteogenesis imperfecta. People with type 1 often have a normal life expectancy, no long-bone deformities, and few childhood fractures. Type 2 osteogenesis imperfecta is the most severe form, with most affected children dying in utero or within the first year of life due to respiratory failure secondary to underdeveloped lungs or intracerebral hemorrhage.
questions.hint: This patient presents with short stature, recurrent bone fractures, blue sclera, and osteopenia, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of short arms and legs. His parents also noticed that his head is progressively enlarging. The patient was born at term via vaginal delivery. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 3rd percentile for height, 25th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows macrocephaly and prominent brow bones. His extremities are short and plump. Muscle strength is 3/5 throughout. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. An x-ray of the lateral skull shows midfacial hypoplasia and frontal prominence. X-rays of the spine show abnormally narrow interpedicular distance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's findings of achondroplasia in combination with generalized hypotonia and hyperreflexia raise suspicion for a complication of the disease. Complications of achondroplasia (e.g., cervicomedullary compression, spinal stenosis, or hydrocephalus) may be life-threatening and, if suspected, warrant immediate action. Reassurance without any active interference is not recommended, since this condition is unlikely to improve spontaneously.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can be used to evaluate cardiovascular conditions in patients with achondroplasia. Patients with this condition are at increased risk for cardiovascular complications, and data from studies suggest that the rate of death due to cardiovascular diseases is increased in these patients compared to the general population. However, while this patient will likely require cardiac evaluation in the future, the presence of hypotonia and hyperreflexia warrants a different intervention at this point in time.

C) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine is used to treat infants with congenital hypothyroidism, which is generally asymptomatic at birth because of transferred maternal thyroid hormone. Symptoms typically manifest in the first few months of life with poor activity and feeding, hypotonia, prolonged neonatal jaundice, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and/or dry skin, all of which are absent in this patient. Additionally, proportionate rather than disproportionate growth restriction would be expected, and frontal bossing is not typically seen in congenital hypothyroidism.

D) CORRECT:

Decreased muscle strength in combination with increased deep tendon reflexes raises suspicion for complications such as brain stem compression and spinal stenosis. Narrowing of the foramen magnum commonly occurs in achondroplasia because of increased growth of the head compared to the torso, which can cause compression of the cervical medulla and lead to subsequent muscular hypotonia/quadriparesis, apnea/hypopnea, and sudden infant death. Neuroimaging is thus indicated at the time of diagnosis to assess the size of the foramen magnum, which is best achieved with CT.

MRI of the head is an alternative neuroimaging tool used to assess the extent of cervicomedullary compression and investigate the cause of cranial enlargement (e.g., hydrocephalus) in infants with achondroplasia.

E) INCORRECT:

Limb-lengthening surgery has, in some centers, been performed to improve final adult height outcome in skeletal dysplasias such as achondroplasia. However specific guidelines regarding age and the sequence of surgery, methods, and extent of lengthening at each stage are controversial. In addition, these procedures are associated with a high risk of morbidity and mortality. Furthermore, this patient presents with hypotonia and hyperreflexia, which warrants a different intervention at this point.

F) INCORRECT:

A short course of testosterone supplementation is indicated in some cases of short stature due to constitutional growth delay, which could start as early as 3 months of age. The absence of any family history in this patient and the other clinical findings (disproportionate growth retardation, frontal bossing, midfacial hypoplasia) make constitutional growth delay, a variant of normal growth pattern, unlikely. In addition, the administration of testosterone in children with constitutional growth delay is only indicated in prepubertal boys to accelerate the onset of pubertal changes and promote linear growth.

G) INCORRECT:

Bisphosphonates are indicated in children with osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), as these medications cause an increase in cortical thickness and significantly increase height. Although OI also manifests with short stature, the absence of other key features such as blue sclera, perinatal traumatic fractures, and hearing loss makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, the growth retardation in this child is disproportionate (short limbs, with average-sized torso), whereas it would be proportionate in OI.
Image Description:

The sclerae show a distinct blue-grey tint.
questions.hint: This patient presents with short stature with an average-sized torso, disproportionately short proximal limbs, macrocephaly, midfacial hypoplasia, and frontal bossing, the combination of which suggests achondroplasia.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Since the age of 2 years, she has had multiple fractures after minor trauma. During the past year, she has fractured the left humerus and right clavicle after falls. Her father also has a history of recurrent fractures. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows increased convexity of the thoracic spine. Forward bend test demonstrates asymmetry of the thoracolumbar region. There is a curvature of the tibias bilaterally, and the left leg is 2 cm longer than the right. There is increased mobility of the joints of the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lens dislocation is associated with Marfan syndrome (upward dislocation) and homocystinuria (downward dislocation). Both conditions cause joint laxity and kyphoscoliosis. However, patients with these conditions usually have tall stature and long limbs while this patient has short stature. Additionally, these conditions do not increase the risk of developing fractures. Lens dislocation is not a feature of OI.

B) CORRECT:

Hearing impairment is a common clinical manifestation of OI, and results from fracture, dislocation, or abnormal formation of the ossicles. Additional findings in patients with OI include blue sclerae (due to choroidal veins appearing through the overlying thin sclerae), easy bruisability, and brittle, opalescent teeth (i.e., dentinogenesis imperfecta). Depending on the type of OI, manifestations may range from mildly symptomatic (type I) to perinatally lethal (type II). This patient likely has moderate to severe OI (comprised of types III-IX) given her early presentation, short stature, and significant bone deformities.

C) INCORRECT:

Widely spaced permanent teeth (Hutchinson teeth) in a child suggest late congenital syphilis. Although this condition can cause skeletal deformities such as tibial bowing, the patient lacks other typical manifestations, including a saddle nose, frontal bossing, a short maxilla, and skin lesions (perioral fissures and gummas). Also, congenital syphilis does not cause joint hypermobility or increase the risk of developing fractures. OI is not associated with Hutchinson teeth but rather brittle, opalescent teeth due to a lack of dentin (i.e., dentinogenesis imperfecta).

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral berry aneurysms are associated with several genetic diseases, including Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), which manifests with joint hypermobility. However, EDS does not cause short stature or increase the risk of developing fractures. Cerebral berry aneurysms are not associated with OI.

E) INCORRECT:

Prominence of the costochondral junctions (rachitic rosary) is characteristic of rickets, which can cause bone deformities (including tibial bowing and kyphoscoliosis) and impaired growth in children, as well as fractures in severe cases. However, rickets does not cause joint hypermobility. Costochondral prominence is not a feature of OI.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased head circumference, or macrocephaly, is a common finding in patients with achondroplasia, which causes disproportionate short stature (along with an average-sized torso and short, plump extremities) and kyphoscoliosis. However, this condition does not cause joint hypermobility or skeletal asymmetry, nor does it increase the risk of developing fractures. Macrocephaly is not a feature of OI.

G) INCORRECT:

Several causes of short stature, including chromosomal abnormalities (Down syndrome, Williams syndrome) and exposure to toxins in utero (embryo-fetal alcohol syndrome), can cause intellectual disability. However, patients with osteogenesis imperfecta typically have normal intelligence.
questions.hint: The patient's short stature, history of fractures after minor trauma, bone deformities (kyphoscoliosis, bowed tibias), joint hypermobility, and family history of recurrent fractures is highly suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI).

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling out from a chair and injuring her right leg. During the past 2 years, she has had two long bone fractures. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her right lower leg is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when her lower leg is touched. A photograph of her face is shown. An x-ray of the right lower leg shows a transverse mid-tibial fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type 4) arises from an autosomal mutation in collagen type 3. This condition manifests predominantly in the cardiovascular system and often goes undiagnosed until it becomes apparent through some sort of vascular damage/injury (e.g., aortic dissection, ruptures arterial aneurysm, subarachnoid hemorrhage). The child presents with easy bruising, as evidenced by the ecchymosis, which is also a feature of Ehlers-Danlos type 4. However, the child's history of frequent fractures after minor trauma, the blue sclerae, and growth retardation are not consistent with this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 5 collagen is a regulator of type 1 collagen fibrillogenesis. Type 5 collagen defects usually manifest as classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by chronic joint and bone issues. Rather than frequent bone fractures, the major symptoms are joint instability, early onset of osteoarthritis, hyperflexible joints, and scoliosis.

C) CORRECT:

A mutation in type 1 collagen causes osteogenesis imperfecta type 1, the mildest and most common form of osteogenesis imperfecta. In fact, some patients with osteogenesis imperfecta type 1 appear normal and without obvious deformities to the casual observer despite requiring special accommodations for their bone fragility. This child presents with blue sclera, short stature, and growth retardation, recurrent fractures from minor falls, and decreased bone density – all classic symptoms of osteogenesis imperfecta.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations to the genes encoding type 4 collagen can present as Alport syndrome. This disorder usually affects boys, who present with intermittent gross hematuria, hearing loss, and ocular disturbances, none of which are seen here. Recurrent bone fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclerae are not features of Alport syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Type 2 collagen defects predominantly affect tissues such as cartilage and the vitreous humor. Various conditions are associated with type 2 collagen defects (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia, or osteoarthritis) and these differ substantially in presentation and age of onset. While some conditions could explain the growth retardation observed in this patient (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia), blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures in an otherwise healthy child would not be consistent with any type 2 collagen defect.
questions.hint: This patient presents with growth retardation, recurrent bone fractures, blue sclera, and osteopenia, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a follow-up examination. He has had a short stature since birth and underwent diagnostic testing. Genetic analyses showed a gain of function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. He has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 90th percentile for weight. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth might raise concern for cleidocranial dysplasia (CCD), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in a transcription factor involved in osteoblast development and is characterized by absent collar bones. CCD typically manifests with mildly disproportionate short stature (short limb length relative to the trunk), other skeletal abnormalities (e.g., delayed closure of cranial sutures, pelvic abnormalities, scoliosis) that often lead to gross motor delay, dental abnormalities (e.g., supernumerary teeth, unerupted permanent teeth), and characteristic facial dysmorphism (wide face, prominent forehead and chin, maxillary hypoplasia).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth should raise concern for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in type 1 collagen genes (COL1A1 or COL1A2) and can manifest with blue sclera. Further symptoms include progressive hearing loss, brittle bones and recurrent pathological fractures, and dentinogenesis imperfecta (brittle, opalescent teeth), none of which is seen in this patient. OI is managed with IV bisphosphonates to decrease the risk of fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

Disproportionately long extremities are characteristic of Marfan syndrome (caused by a mutation in fibrillin-1) and homocystinuria (caused by mutations in enzymes of homocysteine metabolism). Both conditions are associated with tall stature rather than the short stature seen here. Other common features of both Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria include pectus deformity, arachnodactyly, joint hyperlaxity, skin hyperelasticity, and scoliosis, which are absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth may raise concern for Laron syndrome, which is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the growth hormone (GH) receptor gene and can manifest with small genitalia. Laron syndrome typically manifests with disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), distinctive facial dysmorphism (saddle nose, prominent forehead, microcephaly), delayed gross motor developmental milestones and metabolic abnormalities (e.g., osteopenia, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypoglycemia).

E) CORRECT:

Achondroplasia causes disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), characteristic facial dysmorphism (frontal bossing, macrocephaly, midface retrusion, nose flattening), and spinal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis, thoracolumbar kyphosis). Patients with achondroplasia have normal intelligence and typically meet all developmental milestones, as seen here. Approximately 80% of achondroplasia cases are due to sporadic FGFR3 mutations and approximately 20% of cases are caused by autosomal dominant inheritance with full penetrance. The probability of new mutations increases with paternal age at the time of conception.
questions.hint: Constitutive activation of FGFR3 impairs chondrocyte proliferation in the growth plate and is the cause of achondroplasia.

questions.text: A 2860-g (6-lb 3-oz) male newborn is born at term to a primigravid woman via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother has had no routine prenatal care. She reports that there is no family history of serious illness. The initial examination of the newborn shows bowing of the legs and respiratory distress upon palpation of the chest. The skin and joints are hyperextensible. X-rays of the chest and skull show multiple rib fractures and small, irregular bones along the cranial sutures. The patient is at increased risk of which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Costochondral junction enlargement (rachitic rosary) is characteristic of rickets, which can cause bone deformities (including tibial bowing) and impaired growth, as well as fractures in severe cases. However, rickets does not cause skin or joint hypermobility. Costochondral prominence is not a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

B) INCORRECT:

Intestinal rupture is a complication seen in patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), especially the vascular subtype, wherein defective synthesis of collagen type III leads to the formation of fragile tissue that is susceptible to rupture. Affected individuals may present with hyperextensible skin and joints, as seen here, but multiple bone fractures are not a feature of EDS. Intestinal rupture is not associated with osteogenesis imperfecta.

C) INCORRECT:

Several causes of short stature, including chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Down syndrome, Williams syndrome), inborn errors of metabolism (e.g., Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, homocystinuria), and exposure to toxins in utero (e.g., fetal alcohol syndrome), can cause intellectual disability. However, these conditions do not manifest with perinatal fractures and skin and joint hyperextensibility. Patients with osteogenesis imperfecta typically have preserved cognitive ability.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis can occur in patients with achondroplasia, resulting in low back and leg pain, paresthesias, and incontinence. Patients with achondroplasia may also present with respiratory distress due to a small chest cavity and varus deforming of the legs. However, achondroplasia does not cause skin or joint hypermobility, nor does it increase the risk of developing fractures. Spinal stenosis is not a complication of osteogenesis imperfecta.

E) CORRECT:

Hearing loss occurs in patients with OI as a result of bone formation defects such as otosclerosis and ossicle fractures and atrophy. Autosomal dominant mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, which encode the alpha chains of type I collagen, are responsible for most cases of OI. The severe subtypes (types II, III) of OI are usually due to a new (sporadic) mutation in one of these genes, while patients with the mild forms (types I, IV) typically have a parent with the condition. Additional findings in patients with OI include blue sclerae (due to choroidal veins appearing through the overlying thin sclerae), easy bruising, and brittle, opalescent teeth.

In this patient, the described irregular bones around the cranial sutures are indicative of wormian bones. Excessive amounts (> 10) of wormian bones are a feature of OI.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with multiple perinatal fractures, bowing of legs, and hyperextensibility of the skin and joints suggests a diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for follow-up after open reduction and internal fixation of a displaced fracture on the left femoral neck that occurred 2 months ago while she was jogging.
She reports a history of several fractures, including a rib fracture that occurred after she rolled off the couch onto the floor 2 years ago, a humeral fracture that occurred when she fell on the playground as a child, and a fracture of the wrist that occurred after she slipped on ice as a teenager.
She does not note any recent weight gain, does not have a history of menstrual irregularities, and does not use oral contraceptives. She takes no glucocorticoids and has no history of smoking or excess alcohol use. Her parents and siblings do not have a history of nontraumatic fracture.
She is 162.6 cm tall, weighs 61.2 kg, and has a BMI of 23. She has no scoliosis or pain on palpation of the vertebrae or tibiae. Her sclerae have a blue appearance, and she has hyperextensibility of the finger joints.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.2
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
3.5
3.0–4.5


Albumin (g/dL)
4.0
3.5–5.5


Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
25
10–60


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
31
30–80


Fasting cortisol (μg/dL)
11
5–25


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
1.2
0.5–4.7


Hematocrit (%)
39.0
36.0–46.0


Bone densitometry reveals a T score of −2.7 in the lumbar spine and −2.9 in the total hip.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Measurement of the level of fibroblast growth factor 23
Testing for COL1A1 and COL1A2 gene mutations
Testing for a PHEX gene mutation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy would be indicated if multiple myeloma were suspected; however, it is unlikely in an otherwise healthy young patient without anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased level of fibroblast growth factor 23 or the presence of a PHEX gene mutation are features of inherited vitamin D-resistant rickets, such as X-linked hypophosphatemia. However, these patients usually have low serum phosphate levels, short stature, and higher bone mineral density.

C) CORRECT:

Osteogenesis imperfecta is an inherited disorder of type I collagen production. Defects in type I collagen can lead to low bone mineral density, an increase in the frequency of observed fragility fractures, and scoliosis. Some patients have hyperlaxity of joints and blue sclerae. The most common mutations that lead to osteogenesis imperfecta are in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, which code for the alpha chains of type I collagen; therefore, genetic testing for COL1A1 and COL1A2 gene mutations should be the first course of action in the care of this patient. The severity of osteogenesis imperfecta ranges widely, and patients may present with symptoms as children or adults. Treatment usually involves calcium and vitamin D supplementation with bisphosphonate treatment.

Key learning point: A young adult with fragility fractures, normal laboratory values, and findings on physical examination suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta (e.g., blue sclerae, hyperextensible joints) should undergo genetic testing for COL1A1 and COL1A2 gene mutations.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with autosomal dominant type II osteopetrosis have increased fracture incidence and may have the radiographic finding of a rugger-jersey spine, but they typically have elevated bone mineral density.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased level of fibroblast growth factor 23 or the presence of a PHEX gene mutation are features of inherited vitamin D-resistant rickets, such as X-linked hypophosphatemia. However, these patients usually have low serum phosphate levels, short stature, and higher bone mineral density.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for a follow-up examination. He has had a short stature since birth and underwent diagnostic testing. Genetic analyses showed a gain of function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. He has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 90th percentile for weight. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth might raise concern for cleidocranial dysplasia (CCD), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in a transcription factor involved in osteoblast development and is characterized by absent collar bones. CCD typically manifests with mildly disproportionate short stature (short limb length relative to the trunk), other skeletal abnormalities (e.g., delayed closure of cranial sutures, pelvic abnormalities, scoliosis) that often lead to gross motor delay, dental abnormalities (e.g., supernumerary teeth, unerupted permanent teeth), and characteristic facial dysmorphism (wide face, prominent forehead and chin, maxillary hypoplasia).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth should raise concern for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in type 1 collagen genes (COL1A1 or COL1A2) and can manifest with blue sclera. Further symptoms include progressive hearing loss, brittle bones and recurrent pathological fractures, and dentinogenesis imperfecta (brittle, opalescent teeth), none of which is seen in this patient. OI is managed with IV bisphosphonates to decrease the risk of fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

Disproportionately long extremities are characteristic of Marfan syndrome (caused by a mutation in fibrillin-1) and homocystinuria (caused by mutations in enzymes of homocysteine metabolism). Both conditions are associated with tall stature rather than the short stature seen here. Other common features of both Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria include pectus deformity, arachnodactyly, joint hyperlaxity, skin hyperelasticity, and scoliosis, which are absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth may raise concern for Laron syndrome, which is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the growth hormone (GH) receptor gene and can manifest with small genitalia. Laron syndrome typically manifests with disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), distinctive facial dysmorphism (saddle nose, prominent forehead, microcephaly), delayed gross motor developmental milestones and metabolic abnormalities (e.g., osteopenia, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypoglycemia).

E) CORRECT:

Achondroplasia causes disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), characteristic facial dysmorphism (frontal bossing, macrocephaly, midface retrusion, nose flattening), and spinal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis, thoracolumbar kyphosis). Patients with achondroplasia have normal intelligence and typically meet all developmental milestones, as seen here. Approximately 80% of achondroplasia cases are due to sporadic FGFR3 mutations and approximately 20% of cases are caused by autosomal dominant inheritance with full penetrance. The probability of new mutations increases with paternal age at the time of conception.
questions.hint: Constitutive activation of FGFR3 impairs chondrocyte proliferation in the growth plate and is the cause of achondroplasia.

questions.text: You are seeing a 10-year-old boy in your clinic for follow-up. His parents report that he has had short stature since birth, and he has undergone diagnostic testing. Genetic analysis revealed a gain of function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. He has met all developmental milestones. His height is at the 10th percentile and his weight is at the 90th percentile. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth may raise concern for Laron syndrome, which is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the growth hormone (GH) receptor gene and can manifest with small genitalia. Laron syndrome typically manifests with disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), distinctive facial dysmorphism (saddle nose, prominent forehead, microcephaly), delayed gross motor developmental milestones and metabolic abnormalities (e.g., osteopenia, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypoglycemia).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth might raise concern for cleidocranial dysplasia (CCD), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in a transcription factor involved in osteoblast development and is characterized by absent collar bones. CCD typically manifests with mildly disproportionate short stature (short limb length relative to the trunk), other skeletal abnormalities (e.g., delayed closure of cranial sutures, pelvic abnormalities, scoliosis) that often lead to gross motor delay, dental abnormalities (e.g., supernumerary teeth, unerupted permanent teeth), and characteristic facial dysmorphism (wide face, prominent forehead and chin, maxillary hypoplasia).

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's short stature since birth should raise concern for osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in type 1 collagen genes (COL1A1 or COL1A2) and can manifest with blue sclera. Further symptoms include progressive hearing loss, brittle bones and recurrent pathological fractures, and dentinogenesis imperfecta (brittle, opalescent teeth), none of which is seen in this patient. OI is managed with IV bisphosphonates to decrease the risk of fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

Disproportionately long extremities are characteristic of Marfan syndrome (caused by a mutation in fibrillin-1) and homocystinuria (caused by mutations in enzymes of homocysteine metabolism). Both conditions are associated with tall stature rather than the short stature seen here. Other common features of both Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria include pectus deformity, arachnodactyly, joint hyperlaxity, skin hyperelasticity, and scoliosis, which are absent in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Achondroplasia causes disproportionate short stature (average-sized torso with short extremities), characteristic facial dysmorphism (frontal bossing, macrocephaly, midface retrusion, nose flattening), and spinal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis, thoracolumbar kyphosis). Patients with achondroplasia have normal intelligence and typically meet all developmental milestones, as seen here. Approximately 80% of achondroplasia cases are due to sporadic FGFR3 mutations and approximately 20% of cases are caused by autosomal dominant inheritance with full penetrance. The probability of new mutations increases with paternal age at the time of conception.

Key learning point: Achondroplasia is characterized by disproportionate short stature, frontal bossing, midface retrusion, and normal intelligence due to a gain-of-function mutation in the FGFR3 gene.
questions.hint: Constitutive activation of FGFR3 impairs chondrocyte proliferation in the growth plate and is the cause of achondroplasia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after she noticed bruising and swelling over his right arm. They have recently arrived in the USA as refugees from Sudan. She reports that the child probably slid off the couch where he was napping earlier today and that he seems to frequently injuring himself. Vital signs are BP, 98/62 mm Hg; P, 110; R, 24; T, 37.2°C (99°F). Physical examination shows multiple ecchymoses of varying ages over the extremities and shortened, bowed of the lower legs. The right arm is deformed. Radiographs are shown. Laboratory studies show calcium 9.5 mg/dL, phosphate 4.2 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase 75 Units/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bruises and fractures in different stages of healing are characteristic of child abuse, but the presence of generalized osteopenia and limb bowing are not typical findings. These features suggest an underlying bone fragility disorder rather than inflicted injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Rickets may cause bone deformities and bowing, but usually presents with widened growth plates and metaphyseal cupping. Laboratory abnormalities, including low calcium or phosphate and elevated alkaline phosphatase, are typically present and can help differentiate it from other causes of skeletal abnormalities.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypophosphatasia presents with markedly low alkaline phosphatase, impaired bone mineralization, and premature tooth loss. This child’s normal enzyme level and the presence of multiple fractures from minimal trauma are more consistent with osteogenesis imperfecta.

D) INCORRECT:

Campomelic dysplasia presents in the neonatal period with characteristic bowing of long bones, narrow thorax, respiratory distress, and characteristic facial features. Disorders of sex development are often present. It is frequently lethal in infancy. The radiographic pattern of diffuse osteopenia with multiple fractures in an otherwise well child more strongly suggests another diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — Osteogenesis imperfecta is a congenital disorder of type I collagen causing bone fragility, recurrent fractures, and deformities after minimal trauma. Radiographs showing diffuse osteopenia, bowing of long bones, limb shortening, and fractures in various healing stages are typical. Recognition in the ED is essential to distinguish this inherited disorder from inflicted injury and to initiate genetic and orthopedic evaluation.
